metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (an observation system of meteorological elements gradient of A'rou superstation, 2015)
metadata.description:
This data set contains the data of meteorological element gradient observation system of alou superstation, upstream of heihe hydrometeorological observation network, from January 1, 2015 to December 31, 2015.The station is located in caoban village, aru township, qilian county, qinghai province.The longitude and latitude of the observation point are 100.4643e, 38.0473n and 3033m above sea level.The air temperature, relative humidity and wind speed sensors are located at 1m, 2m, 5m, 10m, 15m and 25m respectively, with a total of six layers facing due north.The wind direction sensor is located at 10m, facing due north;The barometer is installed at 2m;The tilting bucket rain gauge is installed on the observation tower 40m of super aru station;The four-component radiometer is installed at 5m, facing due south;Two infrared thermometers are installed at 5m, facing due south, and the probe facing vertically downward.The photosynthetic effective radiometer is installed at 5m, facing due south, and the probe facing vertically upward.Part of the soil sensor is buried at 2m in the south direction of the tower body, and the soil heat flow plate (self-correcting formal) (3 pieces) are all buried at 6cm underground.The mean soil temperature sensor TCAV is buried 2cm and 4cm underground.The soil temperature probe is buried at the surface of 0cm and underground of 2cm, 4cm, 6cm, 10cm, 15cm, 20cm, 30cm, 40cm, 60cm, 80cm, 120cm, 160cm, 200cm, 240cm, 280cm and 320cm, among which the 4cm and 10cm layers have three repeats.The soil water sensor is buried underground 2cm, 4cm, 6cm, 10cm, 15cm, 20cm, 30cm, 40cm, 60cm, 80cm, 120cm, 160cm, 200cm, 240cm, 280cm and 320cm respectively, among which the 4cm and 10cm layers have three duplexes.
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_1 m, Ta_2 m, Ta_5 m, Ta_10 m, Ta_15 m and Ta_25 m; RH_1 m, RH_2 m, RH_5 m, RH_10 m, RH_15 m and RH_25 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_1 m, Ws_2 m, Ws_5 m, Ws_10 m, Ws_15 m and Ws_25 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_2 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) (μmol/(s m-2)), average soil temperature (TCAV, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2 and Gs_3) (W/m2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm_1, Ts_4 cm_2, Ts_4 cm_3, Ts_6 cm, Ts_10 cm_1, Ts_10 cm_2, Ts_10 cm_3, Ts_15 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_30 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, Ts_160 cm, Ts_200 cm, Ts_240 cm, Ts_280 cm and Ts_320 cm) (℃), and soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm_1, Ms_4 cm_2, Ms_4 cm_3, Ms_6 cm, Ms_10 cm_1, Ms_10 cm_2, Ms_10 cm_3, Ms_15 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_30 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_60 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, Ms_160 cm, Ms_200 cm, Ms_240 cm, Ms_280 cm and Ms_320 cm) (%, volumetric water content).
Processing and quality control of observed data :(1) ensure 144 pieces of data every day (every 10min), and mark by -6999 in case of data missing;Soil temperature and humidity, soil heat flux between September 9, 2015 to September 19, 2015 and September 30, 2015 to October 20, 2015 due to power supply problems, data missing;(2) excluding the time with duplicate records;(3) data that obviously exceeds the physical significance or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the part marked with red letter in the data is the data in question;(5) date and time have the same format, and date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: June 10, 2015, 10:30;(6) the naming rule is: AWS+ site name.
For information of hydrometeorological network or station, please refer to Liu et al. (2018), and for observation data processing, please refer to Liu et al. (2011).

Quantification.Question: How many different measurement heights are used for wind speed sensors in a meteorological observation dataset?

Definition.Question: What does 'meteorological gradient observation system' mean in the context of data collection in hydrometeorological networks?
Definition.Answer: A meteorological gradient observation system refers to a structured setup where various meteorological parameters such as air temperature, relative humidity, and wind speed are measured at multiple vertical levels or layers. This system allows for detailed analysis of atmospheric conditions at different heights and helps in understanding the vertical profile of these parameters. In a hydrometeorological network, it is used to collect comprehensive data on atmospheric conditions over a specific region, aiding in ecological and hydrological research.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What underlying factors might cause data gaps or errors during the collection of hydrometeorological data in high-altitude grassland areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data gaps or errors in the collection of hydrometeorological data in high-altitude grassland areas can be caused by issues such as power supply failures, which affected data collection for soil moisture and temperature between certain dates. Additionally, data that is clearly outside the physical or instrumental range is removed, and duplicate records are discarded. Variability in environmental conditions or sensor orientations might also contribute to data discrepancies or uncertainties.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in setting up a meteorological observation system to monitor environmental variables in high-altitude regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The setup involves installing a meteorological observation system with sensors placed at various heights (1m, 2m, 5m, 10m, 15m, 25m) for air temperature and relative humidity, and a wind direction sensor at 10m. Pressure sensors are installed at 2m, and a tipping bucket rain gauge is placed on a 40m observation tower. Radiation instruments are installed at 5m, with infrared thermometers and a photosynthetically active radiation sensor also positioned there. Soil sensors, including soil heat flux plates, soil temperature, and moisture probes, are buried at different depths ranging from 0cm to 320cm. Data collection is performed every 10 minutes, and data quality control measures involve marking missing data, removing duplicates, and eliminating data outside the physical or instrumental range.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and technologies enable the collection of detailed meteorological and soil data in high-altitude grassland environments?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of detailed meteorological and soil data in high-altitude grassland environments is enabled by the strategic placement of multiple sensors at varying heights and depths, such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and soil sensors. Technologies involved include multi-layered sensor systems for air and soil conditions, four-component radiometers, infrared thermometers, and soil moisture sensors. The site conditions, such as its altitude and geographical location, play a crucial role in data collection. Additionally, the data collection process involves rigorous quality control measures to ensure data accuracy, including marking missing data and removing outliers.
